title: 110_hr6845
content: The Act is titled the "Fair Copyright in Research Works Act" and includes limitations on the federal government regarding extrinsic works. The "Fair Copyright in Research Works Act" amends Section 201 of title 17, United States Code, by adding limitations on the Federal Government regarding funding agreements. No Federal agency can impose terms that require the transfer of rights provided under specific sections of the code for extrinsic works. The "Fair Copyright in Research Works Act" limits Federal agencies from imposing terms on funding agreements that require the transfer of rights for extrinsic works. This includes imposing waivers or assent to prohibitions, or asserting rights that restrain the acquisition or exercise of rights in extrinsic works. The "Fair Copyright in Research Works Act" restricts Federal agencies from imposing terms on funding agreements that affect extrinsic works. Prohibited terms shall have no effect under this title. Construction clarifies that certain rights are not limited, and no new copyright protection is created. Definitions include "extrinsic work" as any work not of the US Government based on or derived from other works. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "Federal agency" as any department, agency, or instrumentality of the government. It also defines a government entity that receives funding from sources other than a Federal agency. The curr_chunk defines a "funding agreement" as a contract, grant, or agreement between a Federal agency and a person for research activities. The amendment applies to agreements entered into after the enactment of the Act. The Register of Copyrights must report to Congressional Committees within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Register of Copyrights must report to appropriate congressional committees on the views regarding section 201(f) of title 17, United States Code, considering extrinsic works and materials developed under funding agreements. Definitions for "extrinsic work", "Federal agency", and "funding agreement" are provided in the section. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate, including the Committee on the Judiciary and the Committee on Appropriations.
